awd_titl_txt: Semisolidity and Reactivity of Atmospheric Organic Aerosol Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
Secondary organic aerosols (SOA) are particulate phases that form in the atmosphere through oxidation, transformation and condensation of gas phase, or volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Source VOCs can be either biogenic or man-made compounds.  Recent scientific investigations have demonstrated that some SOA particles exhibit the physical properties of a solid rather than those of liquids normally expected of aerosol. Intermediate behavior of a hard solid of negligible viscosity (>10^12 Pa s) and a thick liquid of high viscosity (<10^2 Pa s) is observed in a transitional range, herein termed semisolid. The diffusion of molecules in such a semisolid may be orders of magnitude slower than in a liquid, yet still fast enough that reactive chemistry can take place. 

The set of questions raised in this project are investigative, even speculative in nature, designed to shed light on the mechanical properties of semisolid SOA, individual (and bulk) properties of aerosols.  A first objective is to quantify how semi-solidity varies with relative humidity and SOA chemistry. A second objective is to measure how chemical reactivity, including both the loss of gas-phase reactants and the appearance of particle-phase products, varies with SOA semi-solidity. The study will make extensive use of an environmental chamber in which VOCs will be oxidized.

The atmospheric occurrence of organic semisolid particles may have important implications for gas uptake and subsequent chemical aging of SOA particles, which in turn are of interest to their climate forcing properties and their effects on public health.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The physical state of atmospheric particles can vary among liquid, semisolid, and solid state. The physical state is an important property in the mechanisms governing the climate and health effects of atmospheric organic particulate matter. It affects volatility and the molecular diffusivity of the constituent organic species, directly affecting rates of reactivity. The three-year study involved the education of students at both undergraduates and graduate levels from many institutions. The combined team effort led to significant advances in the relationships between semisolidity and reactivity for atmospheric organic aerosol particles, as detailed in the published peer-reviewed publications. A specific theme was the discovery of important differences between particles from biogenic compared to anthropogenic precursors.  Accounting for these differences can potentially reduce discrepancies between modeled and observed concentrations of particulate matter in urban regions and their associated climate and health effects.

 

Figure Caption: Contour plot of the characteristic time for evaporation as a function of diffusivity and volatility. Characteristic volatilities associated with intermediate volatility species (IVOC), semivolatile species (SVOC), low volatility species (LVOC), and extremely low volatility species (ELVOC) are labeled on the ordinate. Ranges of diffusivities typically associated with solids, semisolids, and liquids are labeled on the abscissa. For comparison, the ranges estimated in this study for the RH-dependent effective diffusivities of α-pinene-derived and toluene-derived SOM are shown in heavy arrows along the abscissa. Reactivity limited by diffusivity or volatility is highlighted by the heavy arrows.

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2016
Modified by: Scot T Martin
